text: one of the things that is very
irritating if you ever have to go
shopping for you know things to fill a
flight is that there seem to be so many
different types of wineglass it's only a
thing to drink wine out of right it's
got a sort of stem and it's got a flat
bit and it's got a cut bit how
complicated does it need to be and it
turns out that in the case of champagne
especially the shape of the glass does
matter quite a lot so to understand what
shape of champagne glass should be you
first of all need to do to know what the
glass is doing at the bottom of the
glass so there's something very
important is going on because that's the
only part of the glass that's rough if
you've got a if you've got a champagne
glass and it's got bubbles coming from
everywhere around the inside of the
glass I hate to tell you this but the
glass is dirty
don't tell your host it won't make you
popular so in a clean champagne glass
there's a little rough bit at the bottom
and champagne has dissolved gas in it
carbon dioxide at really high pressure
six or seven atmospheres which is one of
the reasons that champagne bottles are
so big and so thick and that gas would
like to come out of solution but it
needs a place to start so that little
roughness at the bottom of the pointy
bit those little sort of grooves in the
glass those are really good places for a
new bubble so that's why bubbles rise
just from the center of the glass and
they rise up in a thin column it's
because that's the place you can make
bubbles so then you've got to worry
about what happens next thing you'll see
the bubbles get a little bit bigger as
they rise because more and more gas is
joining them and as the bubbles go they
don't just move through the fluid they
actually drag liquid with it so that
thin column of bubbles sets up a bubble
engine so fluid the champagne is being
dragged up the middle and then the
bubble stay at the top but the wine has
to come back down the outside so you get
this bubble engine going and that has
two important consequences the first
thing is that it's always bringing new
new champagne to the top and that means
that flavors can get out of the
champagne and into the air above it and
the reason that that matters is because
quite often when we think we're tasting
things what we're actually doing is
smelling things so when you lift a glass
of champagne to your nose just as much
as what's in the wine what matters is in
the air just above it because that's the
bit that goes right up your nose just as
you take a sip
so if you've got a bubble engine that's
going round and round around it's
bringing lots of new champagne to the
top so lots of flavor molecules can get
released into that a little bit of space
the other thing that happens is that
when the bubbles come to the top and
burst they actually do the job for you
they spit little particles up your nose
and so even more flavor gets delivered
upwards so this little bubble engines
really important for the flavor of the
champagne now different glasses drive
that bubble engine in different ways so
if you've got a nice tall champagne
flute the sort of classic thing you get
at parties the bubble engines going
really fast comparatively speaking the
problem is that it's splitting all this
flavor into the air but in your tall
glass if you fill it most of the way up
all the the flavor molecules just
basically escape out of the glass and
disappear so you've wasted them which is
a bit of a shame the other sort of
champagne - you used to see is a coupe a
which is a sort of very flat wide one
like that so this in this case you've
got very shallow depth of champagne so
your bubble engine's going really slowly
so that's really good for allowing lots
of complex molecules to stick to the
bubbles so the flavor molecules that the
bubbles are delivering to the surface
they've got lots of complexities so it's
bringing out all the wonderful things
that are in your wine the problem is
that's the same thing when you when your
flavor is released into the headspace
just above the wine it basically just
blows away so it turns out that the
perfect glass to drink champagne out of
if you're really a wine snob is to pick
something that's about the shape of a
brandy glass but only fill it this far
which is the hard bit because what
happens that then is you get this you
get the slow bubble engine that delivers
lots and lots of complexity into the air
but then it's trapped in all the space
you've got up here so when you lift the
glass to your nose that's when you get
the full benefit of the flavor
